title: Rafa Benitez: Newcastle manager’s future in doubt after club’s failure to buy in January transfer window
text:
Comments RAFA BENITEZ’S long-term Toon future is in doubt over their failure to buy in January. 
The Newcastle boss cannot believe owner Mike Ashley did not bring in a single player and he will demand showdown talks over the summer. PA:Press Association 4 Rafa Benitez’s Newcastle future is in doubt after the club failed to make a winter signing 
He has no intention of quitting in mid-season as he remains confident of guiding them straight back up to the Prem. Keep up to date with ALL the Newcastle news, gossip, transfers and goals on our club page plus fixtures, results and live match commentary 
But the Spaniard, 56, would be forced to consider his future if he does not receive assurances over spending and control. 
Benitez wanted at least two new signings in last month’s window — a winger and back-up for midfielder Jonjo Shelvey. 
He felt it would reinvigorate the squad, as well as the fans, and all but guarantee his second-placed side promotion. Oxford 3-0 Newcastle : Oxford through to fifth round for first time in 23 years PA:Press Association 4 Benitez was desperate to bring Andros Townsend back to St James' Park 
He discussed targets with managing director Lee Charnley long before Christmas and hoped to get players in at the start of January. 
But a frustrating month came to a head on deadline day when Newcastle’s penny-pinching saw them miss out on re-signing Andros Townsend . 
They refused to pay Crystal Palace a £2million loan fee. The deal also came with an obligation to buy the winger for £13m — what they got for him — if Toon went up. Yet Benitez wanted the club to sign him outright now. 
Last summer Rafa was told he had a £30m budget and did not have to sell any of his stars. 
Rafa ended up splashing out more than £55m, but actually made a PROFIT of £30m after selling Moussa Sissoko, Georginio Wijnaldum and Townsend. 
So Benitez cannot work out why there was no cash to spend in January. Getty Images The Spaniard thought there was cash to spend after making a profit on the likes of Moussa Sissoko last summer 
He insists he still has the final say on transfers - and has not been told otherwise. 
But it is evident Ashley’s attitude has changed since the summer, when Benitez was given carte blanche. 
The previously sidelined chief scout Graham Carr appears to have got his influence back at St James’ Park. 
So Benitez wants promises he still retains total control of “all football-related matters”, as the club stated he did when he signed his three-year deal last May. Sunday Premier League match preview featuring Leicester v Man Utd
